snippet.textDisplay:
The kids and I love your videos. We immediately went and did the paper clip and pepper experiments after watching your livestream. BUT now we have more questions!

When we put our paperclips to float in the bowl, WHY do they seem to stick to each other? I know they're steel, but they're not magnetized, and they don't seem to act with any polarity the way magnets would. But it's nearly impossible to get them to float separately-- they always want to clump together like a giant paperclip raft in the middle of the bowl.
snippet.textOriginal:
The kids and I love your videos. We immediately went and did the paper clip and pepper experiments after watching your livestream. BUT now we have more questions! 

When we put our paperclips to float in the bowl, WHY do they seem to stick to each other? I know they're steel, but they're not magnetized, and they don't seem to act with any polarity the way magnets would. But it's nearly impossible to get them to float separately-- they always want to clump together like a giant paperclip raft in the middle of the bowl.

snippet.textDisplay:
I believe astronauts can't weigh themselves in space because there is minimal gravity.
Weight really is a measure of how much an object is pulled on by gravity (and it should be measured in Newtons, but we people are too lazy). Therefore, if we measure the weight of something in space, further away from the centre of the Earth, the Earth won't pull on it as strongly. That's why things weigh less in space and can float around.
Mass is a measure of how many atoms are in an object (or form it, to be specific). Mass is measured in kg, g and so forth.
Maybe the astronauts spin a part of the Spacestation at a certain rate to create a centripetal force (basically a force which pulls things to the centre when something is turning, the opposite of centrifugal force), which is equal to the gravitational force on the surface of the Earth.
Or maybe they don't measure the weight, but the mass of their body. I think they can then convert it to weight by calculating since we know how strong the gravitational force is here on Earth.
Please correct me if I am wrong ;)
snippet.textOriginal:

Therefore, if we measure the weight of something in space, further away from the centre of the Earth, the Earth won't pull on it as strongly. That's why things weigh less in space and can float around.
Mass is a measure of how many atoms are in an object (or form it, to be specific). Mass is measured in kg, g and so forth. 
Maybe the astronauts spin a part of the Spacestation at a certain rate to create a centripetal force (basically a force which pulls things to the centre when something is turning, the opposite of centrifugal force), which is equal to the gravitational force on the surface of the Earth.
Or maybe they don't measure the weight, but the mass of their body. I think they can then convert it to weight by calculating since we know how strong the gravitational force is here on Earth.
Please correct me if I am wrong ;)

snippet.textDisplay:
If we fire a bullet of known mass and calculate bullet's velocity and our velocity then we can calculate our mass using law of conservation of momentum.


Calculation :
(M+m')V=mv
M=(mv/V)-m'
Weight=Mg
M:mass of man
m=mass of bullet
m'=mass of gun
V=recoil velocity of man and gun
v=velocity of bullet
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: We can tie a spring (non deformable spring) on the wall of the space shuttle and tie the other end of the spring to ourselves and throw something away from us to get a force ,and then calculate the time period of oscillation(but do watches work in space?) and we can use T= 2pi (m/k)^1/2 (we can find k by F/x)......and then multiply m by 9.8 to get our weight☺

snippet.textDisplay:
How to weight an astronaut in space:
Have a huge scale mounted to the floor. The astronaut sits on one side. Then you spin the whole space station around to push everything to the floor through centrifugal force. Another astronaut then puts pre measured weights on the other side until the scale evens out.
snippet.textOriginal:
How to weight an astronaut in space:
Have a huge scale mounted to the floor. The astronaut sits on one side. Then you spin the whole space station around to push everything to the floor through centrifugal force. Another astronaut then puts pre measured weights on the other side until the scale evens out.

snippet.textDisplay: If I remember correctly, weight = mass * gravity.  But in space, you don’t have gravity.  However, people like astronauts/fighter pilots have to endure training for certain amounts of G’s (magnitudes of the Earth’s gravity), which can be created by accelerating the ship/plane you are in.  So, if you have no G’s in outer space, you could potentially accelerate to 1 G, the same amount as Earth’s gravity, and have our astronaut hang onto something like a suspended vegetable weight (the plate on a spring).  When they are thrown to the side and a 1 G acceleration is maintained, the forces on the scale should give you the rough reading of what the person’s weight is, because that would be their mass applied to gravity, or in this case, the 1 G supplied.  Just make sure to store the vegetables first before the hard burn.
snippet.textOriginal: If I remember correctly, weight = mass * gravity.  But in space, you don’t have gravity.  However, people like astronauts/fighter pilots have to endure training for certain amounts of G’s (magnitudes of the Earth’s gravity), which can be created by accelerating the ship/plane you are in.  So, if you have no G’s in outer space, you could potentially accelerate to 1 G, the same amount as Earth’s gravity, and have our astronaut hang onto something like a suspended vegetable weight (the plate on a spring).  When they are thrown to the side and a 1 G acceleration is maintained, the forces on the scale should give you the rough reading of what the person’s weight is, because that would be their mass applied to gravity, or in this case, the 1 G supplied.  Just make sure to store the vegetables first before the hard burn.

snippet.textDisplay: I am aware this isn't how it is done, but I like to think it might be a creative way to get an answer. Since the astronauts are in very regulated environments one could do a simple mass balance. Weigh astronauts before leaving earth, as each meal is recorded in space the mass into the body is known, as urine is reycled one could measure liquid via volume out and then caluclate mass via urine density, same with sweat taken from the ambient air in the cabins filtration system (calculated by each astronauts average sweat output as taken on earth and based on body size).  The only item left is the human feces, instead of sending it into the atmosphere to be burned up, one could burn it on the space station and then via energy output derive the associated mass content.  And therefore if you know starting value weight, what goes in and out, you can regualte the weight of the astronaut....not an easy solution but an interesting one :)
snippet.textOriginal: I am aware this isn't how it is done, but I like to think it might be a creative way to get an answer. Weigh astronauts before leaving earth, as each meal is recorded in space the mass into the body is known, as urine is reycled one could measure liquid via volume out and then caluclate mass via urine density, same with sweat taken from the ambient air in the cabins filtration system (calculated by each astronauts average sweat output as taken on earth and based on body size).  The only item left is the human feces, instead of sending it into the atmosphere to be burned up, one could burn it on the space station and then via energy output derive the associated mass content. snippet.textDisplay:
How astronauts weigh themselves?

First I though I could use the equation density equal mass over volume. The volume of an Astronaut/ human being should be consistent. So it could be measure before space. But then you can find volume because liquids don’t stay still in space so that theory was put the window. So the next best option would be to measure their inertia. But, I don’t know how to do that because I haven’t taken AP Physics C in high school yet.

snippet.textDisplay: answer: you dont need gravity to measure weight. What you need is consistent force, a way to measure it, and something you know the weight of. So say you had a treadmill throw you at a wall, and the wall said it felt a measure of force against it. Then lets say you had a bag of potatos and you found it's weight and had the treadmill throw the bag of potatos at the wall. You could run some simple algebra and get your weight. I think theres probably a much much more elegant solution if you have something that can output force, and you know that output well. So a backwards scale, a minecraft piston, whatever.I'm also sure im ignoring some physics. Would there be acelleration? or... the force of the thing throwing you would probably be exponentially weaker at throwing you, the heavier you are. Or more accurately the output or the impact would be less, the heavier you are.
snippet.textOriginal: answer: you dont need gravity to measure weight. What you need is consistent force, a way to measure it, and something you know the weight of. So say you had a treadmill throw you at a wall, and the wall said it felt a measure of force against it. Then lets say you had a bag of potatos and you found it's weight and had the treadmill throw the bag of potatos at the wall. You could run some simple algebra and get your weight. I think theres probably a much much more elegant solution if you have something that can output force, and you know that output well. So a backwards scale, a minecraft piston, whatever.I'm also sure im ignoring some physics. Would there be acelleration? or... the force of the thing throwing you would probably be exponentially weaker at throwing you, the heavier you are. Or more accurately the output or the impact would be less, the heavier you are.

snippet.textDisplay: For the question about weighing astronauts in space - Weight is the force we are looking for. We already have a constant mass. What’s missing is the acceleration due to gravity. So as long as the astronauts in question are in a rocket and somehow they are able to simulate this acceleration by thrusting forwards in their rocket while standing on a scale - They should be able to find out how much they weigh..All thanks to dear old Newton and his 2nd law.
snippet.textOriginal: For the question about weighing astronauts in space - Weight is the force we are looking for. We already have a constant mass. What’s missing is the acceleration due to gravity. So as long as the astronauts in question are in a rocket and somehow they are able to simulate this acceleration by thrusting forwards in their rocket while standing on a scale - They should be able to find out how much they weigh..All thanks to dear old Newton and his 2nd law.

snippet.textDisplay: Weighing an astronaut in space... What about a tilt-a-whirl like device that utalizes centrifugal force and a pressure sensor. snippet.textDisplay:
My answer is that you weigh an astronaut in space by throwing him at a wall/sensor and seeing how hard he hits.
If you throw a ping pong ball and a bowling ball at someone in space even though they are both "weightless" the one that has more mass will hit much harder.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: I have a problem when you call water "magnetic". It is a polar molecule, it has significant Van De Walls forces, but I call it para-magnetic, as I heard from Dianna. Your sweeping generalities interfere with the "mind model" that you seek. If you attract younger people people to science, do you really think throwing the placards at the camera is helpful? It does not fit the idea of exactness that this EE wants.Your bouancy class was a bit fast and loose with mass, force(weight), and density. You are close, Mark, but don't quit your day job. (Which I guess is monthly videos with So Rediculus (sp).)
snippet.textOriginal: I have a problem when you call water "magnetic". It is a polar molecule, it has significant Van De Walls forces, but I call it para-magnetic, as I heard from Dianna. Your sweeping generalities interfere with the "mind model" that you seek. If you attract younger people people to science, do you really think throwing the placards at the camera is helpful? snippet.textDisplay: By centrifugation
snippet.textOriginal: By centrifugation

snippet.textDisplay: My idea for the next class: We use centrifugal force to our advantage. Let's say we attach some object- possibly a person- To a one meter long wooden plank or iron rod, or some other long, solid object. Then attach the other end of the rod to a motor which spins the rod and the person in a big 1 meter radius circle. If they spin at about 3.13 m/s, the centripetal acceleration they'll feel would be 3.13 squared, or 9.81 m/s^2- exactly the same acceleration that we feel by Earth's gravity. From there we just measure the centrifugal "force" on the person, and boom. We've just measured their weight in zero gravity.
snippet.textOriginal: My idea for the next class: We use centrifugal force to our advantage. Let's say we attach some object- possibly a person- To a one meter long wooden plank or iron rod, or some other long, solid object. Then attach the other end of the rod to a motor which spins the rod and the person in a big 1 meter radius circle. If they spin at about 3.13 m/s, the centripetal acceleration they'll feel would be 3.13 squared, or 9.81 m/s^2- exactly the same acceleration that we feel by Earth's gravity. From there we just measure the centrifugal "force" on the person, and boom. We've just measured their weight in zero gravity.

snippet.textDisplay: Answer: this is definitely not how they do it, but technically you could have an object of known mass and set the astronaut and the object at a set distance and take different measurements every couple minutes and find acceleration and with a combination of F=ma and F= Gm1m2/d^2 find the astronauts mass and then convert in to weight on earth at sea level with the F=ma again
snippet.textOriginal: Answer: this is definitely not how they do it, but technically you could have an object of known mass and set the astronaut and the object at a set distance and take different measurements every couple minutes and find acceleration and with a combination of F=ma and F= Gm1m2/d^2 find the astronauts mass and then convert in to weight on earth at sea level with the F=ma again

The band would have to be on your head...tough question!

snippet.textDisplay: I know this is going to sound like the most ridiculous answer to the question for next week but a way for astronauts to weigh themselves when they're weightless is they have would need to be in a object that has a lot of thirst like a rocket or a space pod. Tape a scale to the floor of the pod and then point the thrusters facing down to propel you up. Put them on full blast and make sure that you are standing above the scale when the rocket goes the up while you are in zero gravity it will move closer to you. Then you stand on top of it using the g-forces to creat the pressure of pushing you down which should give you a weight measurement although it my not be accurate.
snippet.textOriginal: I know this is going to sound like the most ridiculous answer to the question for next week but a way for astronauts to weigh themselves when they're weightless is they have would need to be in a object that has a lot of thirst like a rocket or a space pod.
